popt4jlib.GradientDescent.stochastic

Class Adam

  • java.lang.Object
    • popt4jlib.GradientDescent.stochastic.Adam
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, LocalOptimizerIntf, OptimizerIntf

    public class Adam
extends java.lang.Object
implements LocalOptimizerIntf
    A multi-threaded implementation of the Adam algorithm for stochastic optimization. See D.P. Kingma and J.L. Ba (2015): "ADAM: A method for stochastic optimization", arXiv:1412.6980v8 [cs.LG]. The authors of the paper claim their method to be particularly well-suited for large-scale online sparse learning problems. The method is supposed to work when the function to be optimized is a noisy objective function f(θ) and the objective is to find the parameters that minimize the expected value E[f(θ)] of the function when evaluated at θ. The stochastic nature of the function f in ML problems (when solved especially via ANNs) usually comes forth when the function is evaluated at random samples of the entire training set (see the popt4jlib.neural package, and in particular the popt4jlib.neural.FFNN4Train[B] classes for more details.)

    Title: popt4jlib

    Description: A Parallel Meta-Heuristic Optimization Library in Java

    Copyright: Copyright (c) 2011-2020

    Company:

    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Ioannis T. Christou
    See Also:

      • minimize

        public PairObjDouble minimize(FunctionIntf f)
                       throws OptimizerException
        the main method of the class. Before it is called, a number of parameters must have been set (via the parameters passed in the constructor, or via a later call to setParams(p)). These are:
        • <"adam.numthreads", Integer nt> optional, the number of threads to use in the optimization process. Default is 1.
        • <"adam.numtries", Integer ntries> optional, the number of initial starting points to use (must either exist then ntries <"adam.x$i$",VectorIntf v> pairs in the parameters or a pair <"[gradientdescent.]x0",VectorIntf v> pair in params). Default is 1.
        • <"adam.gradient", VecFunctionIntf g> optional the gradient of f, the function to be minimized. If this param-value pair does not exist, the gradient will be computed via Richardson finite differences extrapolation.
        • <"adam.gtol", Double v> optional, the minimum abs. value for each of the gradient's coordinates, below which if all coordinates of the gradient happen to be, the search stops assuming it has reached a stationary point. Default is 1.e-6.
        • <"adam.maxiters", Integer miters> optional, the maximum number of major iterations of the search before the algorithm stops. Default is Integer.MAX_VALUE.
        • <"adam.a", Double val> optional, the alpha step-size parameter of the Adam algorithm. Default is 0.001.
        • <"adam.b1", Double val> optional the β_1 exponential decay rate for moment estimates. Default is 0.9.
        • <"adam.b2", Double val> optional the β_2 exponential decay rate for moment estimates. Default is 0.999.
        • <"adam.eps", Double val> optional the ε factor in update parameter estimation. This value is also used to detect convergence -and so stop the algorithm- of the variables x. Default is 1.e-8.
        Specified by:
        minimize in interface OptimizerIntf
        Parameters:
        f - FunctionIntf the function to minimize
        Returns:
        PairObjDouble the pair containing the arg. min (a VectorIntf) and the min. value found
        Throws:
        OptimizerException - if another thread is currently executing the same method or if the method fails to find a minimizer

      • getNumOK

        public int getNumOK()
        auxiliary method.
        Returns:
        int the number of "tries" that succeeded (found a stationary point)

      • getNumFailed

        public int getNumFailed()
        auxiliary method.
        Returns:
        int the number of tries that failed (did not find a saddle point)
